I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to The University of the South Pacific (USP) for the Higher 
Education in the Pacific Investment Program.1 
 
2.  The proposed investment program will support USP in expanding access to higher 
education in its 12 member Pacific island countries (PICs) by improving physical environments 
and learning programs.2 The investment program will include (i) expanding regional campuses 
and accommodation facilities in Kiribati, Solomon Islands, and Fiji; (ii) enhancing information 
and communication technology (ICT)-based distance learning programs; (iii) improving student 
services; and (iv) strengthening USP governance and management capacity. Improved access 
to quality higher education at USP will contribute to human resource and skills development in 
the Pacific and will promote inclusive growth enabled by higher productivity and diversification of 
the region’s economy.3 
 
II.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The  Pacific  region  shares  common  challenges  for  sustainable  development  due  to 
geographic remoteness, small domestic markets, and a narrow industrial base. Building resilient 
and  sustainable  economies  requires  a  strong  workforce  with  required  technical  skills  and 
managerial competencies. Currently, many countries in the region face shortages of trained 
professionals and technical personnel, who can adopt new technologies, drive innovation, and 
manage business and government effectively. Of the total population of 2.3 million in the 12 
PICs, more than half are under the age of 25. If adequately educated and trained, they can 
become critical drivers of sustainable development in the Pacific. Research indicates that higher 
education  in  developing  countries  not  only  increases  individual  productivity  and  earnings 
potential, but it produces a professional work force, creates entrepreneurial activities with a 
greater number of jobs, and strengthens governance, thereby leading to poverty reduction and 
economic development.4     
 
4.  Limited higher education opportunities. In the Pacific, the gross enrollment ratio for 
higher education ranges from 10% in Fiji to 2%–5% in most other PICs.5 Low enrollment is 
attributable to several factors. Physical capacities and program coverage in higher education in 
the region are limited. Many potential employers perceive that the quality of higher education 
programs available in the Pacific is not sufficient to provide graduates with the relevant skills 
and competencies required in the labor market. Therefore, students seek opportunities to attend 
higher education outside the region, such as in Australia and New Zealand. Such education is 
unaffordable  for  most  students,  especially  those  from  low-income  households;  only  5%  of 
students  seeking  an  overseas  education  can  obtain  government  scholarships  or  private 
sponsorship.  
 
                                                
1  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

the Asian Development Bank; these are small island countries with a combined total population of 2,800. Niue had 
57 students and Tokelau had 79 students enrolled at USP in 2011.

5.  Region’s objectives for higher education. The Pacific Plan—the region’s high-level 
strategy endorsed by Pacific Island Forum leaders in 2005—regards an educated population as 
a prerequisite to achieving the common goals of economic growth, sustainable development, 
good governance, and security. The plan emphasizes strengthening regional cooperation and 
integration to achieve these common goals and identifies the regional provision of public goods 
and services as an important area of regional cooperation. Services, such as higher education, 
that are costly and inefficient for small island countries to provide at the national level will benefit 
from regional cooperation through economies of scale.  In this regard, USP is expected to play a 
leading  role  in  the  region’s  collective  commitment  to  improve  access  to  quality  higher 
education.6   
 
6.  USP’s regional leadership. USP was established in 1968 by the governments of 12 
PICs to meet the regional challenges of higher education.7 USP’s regional role is demonstrated 
by its 14 campuses across the 12 PICs, its student composition, governance, and approaches 
to education delivery. The USP council, currently chaired by Samoa, is the highest decision-
making and governing body of USP and comprises 35 members from the 12 PICs, Australia, 
New Zealand, and the Pacific Island Forum Secretariat. USP’s main campus, located in Suva, 
Fiji (Laucala campus), hosts the recently established Japan–Pacific ICT Center, which will 
coordinate and broadcast ICT-based distance and flexible learning (DFL) programs across the 
12 member countries.   
 
7.  In 2011, approximately 22,000 students were enrolled in USP’s predegree or degree 
programs  across the member countries,  which  was  an  increase  of  10% from  2010. Total 
enrollment is expected to increase further by 16% in 2012. Although precise estimates are not 
available, more than three-quarters of all higher education students across the 12 PICs are 
enrolled in USP. Students from Solomon Islands and Vanuatu constitute the second largest 
shares of USP enrollment (12% of total each), next to those from Fiji; students from Kiribati and 
Tonga make up the next largest groups (4% of total each). Despite increases in enrollment from 
these countries, attendees still represent only a small proportion of those in the 17–22 age 
group. As secondary enrollment has been increasing, there is growing demand for higher 
education, but the USP regional campuses, such as in Kiribati and Solomon Islands, are limited 
in physical capacities and academic programs. ICT-based DFL programs with a high degree of 
flexibility will enable USP to reach out to remote parts of the Pacific and to those who cannot 
afford full-time studies. Currently, about 40% of USP students study through DFL programs. 
 
8.  Regional road map for higher education.8  To achieve the regional vision of the 
Pacific Plan and to meet changing global and regional needs, USP has initiated a range of 
reforms. The USP Strategic Plan 2010–2012: Quality, Relevance, and Sustainability has been 
implemented to enhance the quality and relevance of learning and teaching programs.9 The 
new strategic plan for 2013–2018 aims to further reshape the strategic focus of USP, while 
expanding its provision of quality higher education across the region. These strategic plans, 
together with the Pacific Plan, represent the regional road map for higher education. The

investment program will strengthen USP’s regional role and support four priority areas in the 
road map: (i) improvement and expansion of the USP regional campuses, (ii) enhancement of 
ICT-based  learning  programs  and  curricula,  (iii)  development  of  academic  and  career 
counseling services, and (iv) improvement of USP governance and management systems. 
 
9.  Policy  support  at  the  national  level.  National  development  strategies  in  PICs 
recognize the importance of education for inclusive and sustainable development. For example, 
the  draft  Kiribati  Development  Plan  2012–2015  identifies  limited  opportunities  for  higher 
education and training as a major constraint to increasing economic productivity, and prioritizes 
its commitment to enhance the relevance of higher education to local and overseas employment. 
Kiribati has been urging USP to expand its local campus and extend undergraduate programs to 
permit Kiribati students to complete undergraduate studies in-country. Similarly, the National 
Development  Strategy  2011–2020  for  Solomon  Islands  emphasizes  improved  access  to 
education as an essential requirement for reducing poverty and improving the lives of Solomon 
Islanders. Recognizing the high costs of overseas education, the Government of Solomon 
Islands views the development of in-country training as a more cost-effective option over the 
long term, and has proposed the establishment of a full USP campus in Solomon Islands that 
will make an optimal use of technology to facilitate online and DFL programs. 
 
10.  ADB’s strategic context. Aligned with the Pacific Plan and ADB’s Strategy 2020,10 
ADB’s Pacific Approach 2010–2014 sets regional cooperation and integration as a priority goal, 
along with inclusive and sustainable growth and good governance.11 This investment program is 
consistent with the direction of ADB’s Pacific Approach. It represents ADB’s first investment 
support for higher education at the regional level in the Pacific, building on past engagements in 
the  education  and  training  sector  through  regional  technical  assistance  and  capacity 
development activities. ADB support will also complement the activities of other development 
partners supporting USP, such as the Australian Agency for International Development, the 
European Union, the Government of India, the Japan International Cooperation Agency, and the 
New Zealand Aid Programme.12  
 
11.  By supporting USP’s regional role in the provision of higher education, ADB will promote 
regional  integration  activities  in  the  Pacific  while  helping  PIC  governments  free  up  limited 
resources for investments in primary and secondary education. Enabling USP to expand the 
highly skilled work force will contribute to human resource development in the region, which can 
foster a private sector-driven economy, advance the business environment, and strengthen 
governance. Supporting USP’s ICT-based DFL programs will also reinforce ADB’s regional 
strategy of enhancing connectivity and social service delivery through ongoing ICT investments. 
 
12.  Financing modality. An MFF is proposed as the financing modality, consisting of three 
tranches to be implemented over 8 years. The MFF modality is proposed, as it (i) provides long-
term support to USP for the phased implementation of individual projects based on project 
readiness,  (ii)  allows  for  timely  arrangements  of  the  required  sovereign  guarantees  for 
subsequent tranches, and (iii) aligns ADB support with assistance provided to USP by other 
development partners.  
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The expected impact of the investment program is that USP graduates will contribute to 
the competitiveness and diversification of PIC economies. The expected outcome is expanded

women and students from remote outer islands. 
 
C.  Outputs 
14.  The overall investment program has five outputs: (i) output 1: strengthened regional 
campuses of USP, (ii) output 2: enhanced ICT-based education, (iii) output 3: improved USP 
student services, (iv) output 4: strengthened USP governance and management, and (v) output 
5: strengthened project management capacity of USP.  
 
15.  Tranche 1 will support outputs 1, 2, 4, and 5, with the following major activities: 
 
(i)  Enhanced regional campus and ICT-based education in Kiribati. The USP 
Kiribati campus will be expanded to accommodate the rapidly increasing number 
of  students  by  constructing  additional  classrooms,  an  ICT  studio,  a  student 
cafeteria, and administration facilities. New ICT equipment will be provided to 
connect to other regional campuses, and deliver faster and more reliable ICT-
based learning courses, especially DFL courses. 
 
(ii)  Strengthened  USP  governance  and  management.  The  education 
management information system will be enhanced by collecting, analyzing, and 
disseminating  accurate and  timely  statistical  data  about  USP’s  activities  and 
human  resources  (e.g.,  student,  faculty,  and  alumni  data)  to  support  USP 
management and operations. All data will be disaggregated by sex. 
 
(iii)  Strengthened project management capacity. Project management capacity 
will be supported by establishing a project implementation unit (PIU) within USP, 
which  will  manage  all  project  activities  (e.g.,  procurement,  accounting,  and 
monitoring). 
 
16.  Subsequent tranches will support activities under outputs 1–5 with a focus on expanding 
the Solomon Islands campus and enhancing student support services. The USP Solomon 
Islands campus will be expanded and upgraded with additional classrooms, an ICT studio, 
science laboratories, dormitories, and faculty offices. The upgraded facilities will be provided 
with ICT equipment allowing students to learn through face-to-face, DFL, or blended methods. 
Additional e-learning materials will be produced and ICT connectivity improved to make a wide 
range of courses available for students across USP regional campuses. 
 
17.  To improve student support services, pre-enrollment services will focus on providing 
accurate information about curricular choice. Career counseling services will be established to 
facilitate  skills  assessments,  job  search  processes,  and  links  to  available  employment 
opportunities. A new dormitory will be constructed at the Laucala main campus to accommodate 
regional students at the degree or graduate levels, especially female students with families. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
18.  The investment program is estimated to cost $23 million, including taxes and duties of 
$1 million (Table 1).  USP has requested an MFF in an amount up to $19 million equivalent from 
Special Funds resources with a third party sovereign guarantee to help finance part of the 
investment program. The MFF will consist of three tranches, subject to USP’s submission of 
related periodic financing requests (PFRs); availability of a sovereign guarantee; execution of 
the  related  loan  agreement  for  each  tranche;  and  fulfillment  of  terms,  conditions,  and 
undertakings set forth in the framework financing agreement (FFA).13 Tranche 1 will have a 32-

19.  Tranche 1. USP submitted the first PFR14 in line with the FFA. The tranche 1 project is 
estimated to cost $3.975 million equivalent, including taxes and duties of $300,000, physical 
and price contingencies, and interest charges during implementation. The PFR is for a loan in 
various currencies equivalent to SDR 1,692,000 from ADF resources to finance 65.5% of the 
total cost of the project.15 USP will provide counterpart financing of $0.375 million and the 
Government of Kiribati $1 million. 
 
20.  As a financing facility to a regional entity comprising ADB’s Pacific developing member 
countries  (DMCs)  and  other  members,  and  guaranteed  by  ADB  members,  the  proposed 
financing is classified as public sector financing. Direct lending to USP is consistent with the 
Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter), which specifies that ADB 
may  finance  international  or  regional  agencies  or  entities  concerned  with  economic 
development of the region, as well as with ADF regulations.16 USP is a regional entity that will 
directly contribute to the economic development of the Pacific region. The investment program’s 
regional design and impact aim to benefit students particularly from economically vulnerable 
ADF-eligible DMCs for an education sector intervention with high developmental priority.17  
 
21.  The loan for the tranche 1 project requires a sovereign guarantee; the Government of 
Kiribati has agreed to serve as a guarantor. ADB is in discussion with other Pacific DMCs and 
ADB member countries to seek similar guarantee arrangements for subsequent tranches. USP 
will provide counterpart financing of $2 million equivalent for the entire program. 
 
22.  Framework financing agreement. USP and the Government of Kiribati (as sovereign 
guarantor)  have  entered  into  an  FFA  with  ADB  that  includes  comprehensive  assurances, 
warranties, and representations in relation to safeguards, governance, anticorruption, financial 
management, procurement, and disbursement. As a condition to ADB accepting to act upon any 
PFR for tranche 1, the Government of Kiribati will ensure full compliance with the terms and 
conditions of the FFA.  
 
23.  USP  has  requested  ADB  to  consider  providing  additional  resources  from  its  ADF 
resources for subsequent tranches. Any additional ADF allocation will be subject to the general 
availability of ADF resources from time to time. Tranche 2, which will support expansion of the 
USP campus located in Solomon Islands, along with other project activities, is estimated to cost  
$15.78 million with proposed ADF financing of approximately $13.55 million. Tranche 3, which 
will support establishment of a dormitory for regional students at the Laucala main campus of 
USP, will cost a total of $3.25 million with proposed ADF financing of $2.85 million.18

E.  Implementation Arrangements

overall guidance for project implementation and facilitate cross-agency dialogue. The PSC will

procurement, civil works, finance, and contract management. The implementation arrangements 
are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the facility administration manual.19

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical 
25.  The investment program will fund the construction of additional facilities at the USP 
Kiribati campus in Tarawa, the expansion of the USP Solomon Islands campus in a new 
location in Honiara, and the construction of a dormitory at the existing USP Laucala campus. 
The Kiribati campus in Tarawa will be constructed on the existing USP site, which is located on 
government-owned  land.  For  tranche  2,  the  Government  of  Solomon  Islands  will  provide 
assurance that the new campus site in Honiara is government-owned land, with valid legal title, 
free from all encumbrances and controversies. The projects under the investment program will 
seek international firms to manage the design, construction, and equipping of the new facilities. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
26.  The economic and financial analyses show that the investment program will satisfy 
ADB’s economic and financial evaluation criteria, and that the tranche 1 project would have an 
economic internal rate of return of 15.7% and a financial internal rate of return of 12.3%.20

27.  With the 2009 appointment of the current vice-chancellor who put forward the Strategic 
Plan  2010–2012,  USP’s  financial  position  has  improved  significantly  in  recent  years.  The 
improvement  resulted  from  rigorous  restructuring  efforts  that  included  payroll  cuts,  faculty 
consolidation, and expansion and enhancement of revenue generating opportunities on USP 
campuses. The  stronger financial  position  and  managerial  capacity  has,  in  turn,  prompted 
increased  support  from  bilateral  development  partners.  Audited  financial  accounts  show 
operating surplus equivalent to about $3.4 million for 2008, $8.2 million for 2009, and $2.5 
million for 2010. These surpluses represented 4.0%, 12.4%, and 3.4% of total operating income 
for these 3 years, which contrasts with operating deficits earlier in the decade. The positive 
financial outcomes are expected to continue, with USP’s operating surplus for 2011 estimated at 
$3.5 million. 
 
28.  Economic benefits of the tranche 1 project derive mainly from increased employment 
and higher salaries commanded by USP graduates compared with the labor market outcomes 
expected for Kiribati youths without undergraduate education. Project economic benefits include 
an estimated value of positive externalities to Kiribati society from having a more educated 
population (e.g., more entrepreneurial activity, improved civil engagement, better public health 
outcomes), which is assumed modestly at 5% of the value of higher earnings. Records show a 
high attrition rate for Kiribati students at USP. This has been improving, and the analysis 
assumes that the upgrading of the USP Kiribati campus will reduce attrition rates modestly by 
4.5%.21 The actual campus upgrading is expected to bring more significant improvements in 
student completion rates, and hence the economic internal rate of return would be much higher. 
  
29.  An assessment of USP’s financial management capacity concluded that current financial 
control mechanisms are robust and procurement capacity is adequate. For the investment 
program, a dedicated PIU, which will include a financial specialist, will be established within 
USP’s Development, Marketing, and Communications Division. The PIU will oversee technical, 
procurement, and disbursement processes. ADB will provide capacity-building support to the 
PIU to ensure that all financial reporting and procurement procedures are in compliance with 
ADB guidelines and procedures. 
 
C.  Governance 
30.  As the only regional higher education institution in the Pacific, USP is expected to 
provide a model for good practice in governance and to operate ethical, transparent, and 
effective systems. In 2009, the USP council and management decided that a comprehensive 
governance and management enhancement strategy was required to position USP to meet the 
overarching goals in the Pacific. This view was translated into the strategic plans for 2010–2012 
and 2013–2018, one priority of which is to “increase effectiveness of governance, administrative, 
and management systems.” The investment program directly supports this priority as indicated 
in the road map. The appointment of a new vice-chancellor in 2009 also saw a marked shift in 
USP direction and performance. The work of the USP governance committee was accelerated, 
and significant improvements were made in transparency, due diligence, and risk management. 
 
31.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with USP. An assessment of procurement capacity found that USP has a robust procurement 
system, knowledgeable staff, and clear guidelines. Additional support for capacity development 
will ensure compliance with ADB guidelines and procedures. 
 
                                                
21 Assumptions about graduation and employment rates of Kiribati students at USP are based on reported graduation 
rates in 2009 and 2010, and the results of the USP graduate destination surveys for 2009–2010 and 2011.

9 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
32.  The  expansion  of  USP  campuses  in  Kiribati  and  Solomon  Islands,  together  with 
extensive  outreach  activities,  will  allow  more  equitable  opportunities  for  higher  education, 
especially for young people from poor and disadvantaged backgrounds. Higher education for 
these young people will, in turn, improve their employment and earnings potential, providing 
them with a greater ability to enhance economic conditions and social mobility. These individual 
benefits will cumulate into improved quality of life in the region. The improved quality of the USP 
academic programs will also increase the pool of qualified individuals who contribute to inclusive 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction  in  the  region.  Recent  evidence  suggests  that 
investment in higher education produces both private and public benefits, such as improved 
health  status,  reduced  population  growth,  use  of  innovative  technology,  and  strengthened 
governance (footnote 4). Improved quality of higher education will also enable Pacific islanders 
to find overseas employment, and contribute to the home economy with remittances or by 
returning to home countries with advanced knowledge and better entrepreneurial skills. 
 
33.  The tranche 1 project is categorized as effective gender mainstreaming. To address 
gender-specific concerns in the project, a gender action plan was prepared for the investment 
program and for tranche 1. The plan for tranche 1 will promote increased enrollment for women 
(as well as men) in the USP Kiribati campus, especially in degree programs and e-learning DFL 
programs. The target is for at least 30% of all registered female students in the Kiribati campus 
to be enrolled in degree programs by 2018. The project will also promote the participation of 
female staff in all USP management committees. During the construction of new facilities, 
employment opportunities will be provided for women as well as men.  
 
E.  Safeguards 
34.  Environment. The tranche 1 project is classified as category B in accordance with 
ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). An initial environmental examination was prepared 
to assess and review the process for project implementation.22 Civil works under tranche 1 may 
have  minor  adverse  environmental  impacts  such  as  noise  and  traffic  congestion  during 
construction. Measures to mitigate such impacts and monitoring and compliance tasks are 
outlined in the initial environmental examination in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement and all applicable environmental laws and regulations of Kiribati.  
 
35.  Social safeguards. The tranche 1 project is classified as category C for both involuntary 
resettlement and indigenous peoples in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
The project does not involve land acquisition or involuntary resettlement impacts. All civil works 
will be undertaken on land currently being used by USP or on land provided by the government 
free of any claims or encumbrances. The project is not expected to affect any distinct and 
vulnerable groups of indigenous peoples as defined under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
36.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.23

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
37.  USP has assured ADB that implementation of the project will conform to all applicable 
ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures,  safeguards,  gender, 
procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as  described  in  detail  in  the  facility 
administration manual and the loan documents. USP and the Government of Kiribati have given 
ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, which are set forth in the FFA. Specific covenants 
agreed to by USP with respect to individual tranches under the MFF are set forth in the loan 
agreement for the respective tranches. In addition, USP has agreed to the following specific 
assurances  with  respect  to  tranche  1,  which  will  be  conditions  for  loan  effectiveness:  
(i) agreement with the Government of Kiribati on a sovereign guarantee for tranche 1; and (ii) a 
project facilitation letter from the Government of Kiribati that assures land lease rights, in-kind 
contributions  for  taxes  and  duties,  and  safeguard  compliance.  Finalization  of  a  site  lease 
between the Government of Kiribati and USP for the Kiribati campus where civil works are to be 
undertaken will be a condition for disbursement of the tranche 1 loan proceeds for such civil 
works. 
   
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an aggregate principal 
amount not exceeding $19,000,000 equivalent to The University of the South Pacific for the 
Higher  Education  in the  Pacific  Investment  Program  comprising  loans from  ADB’s  Special 
Funds resources, with interest and other terms to be determined in accordance with ADB’s then 
applicable  policies  relating  to  Special  Funds  resources,  subject  to  conditions  set  forth  in 
paragraph  23  of  this  report,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in the framework financing agreement presented to the Board.
